title: useNumericLiterals
description: |
  Disallow `parseInt()` and `Number.parseInt()` in favor of binary, octal, and hexadecimal literals
---
import { Tabs, TabItem } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';

**Diagnostic Category: `lint/style/useNumericLiterals`**
<Tabs>
<TabItem label="JavaScript (and super languages)" icon="seti:javascript">
**Since**: `v1.0.0`
:::note
- This rule has an **unsafe** fix.
:::

Sources: 
- Same as: <a href="https://eslint.org/docs/latest/rules/prefer-numeric-literals" target="_blank"><code>prefer-numeric-literals</code></a>

## Description
Disallow `parseInt()` and `Number.parseInt()` in favor of binary, octal, and hexadecimal literals

_JavaScript_ provides literal forms for binary, octal, and hexadecimal numbers.
For example: `0b11`, `0o77`, and `0xff`.
Using the literal forms enable static code analysis and avoid unnecessary computations.

## Examples

### Invalid

```js
parseInt("111110111", 2);
```

```js
Number.parseInt("767", 8);
```

```js
Number.parseInt("-1f7", 16);
```

### Valid

```js
parseInt(1);
parseInt(1, 3);
Number.parseInt(1);
Number.parseInt(1, 3);

0b111110111 === 503;
0o767 === 503;
0x1F7 === 503;

a[parseInt](1,2);

parseInt(foo);
parseInt(foo, 2);
Number.parseInt(foo);
Number.parseInt(foo, 2);
```

## How to configure
```json title="biome.json"
{
	"linter": {
		"rules": {
			"style": {
				"useNumericLiterals": "error"
			}
		}
	}
}

```
